dt: {bc}an exclusive or special right, power, or {d_link|privilege|privilege:1}: such as
{bc}one belonging to an office or an official body
{bc}one belonging to a person, group, or class of individuals
{bc}one possessed by a nation as an attribute of {d_link|sovereignty|sovereignty}
{bc}the discretionary power {d_link|inhering|inhere} in the British Crown

quotes.t: That sense that the future may not last for long is often assumed to be a {qword}prerogative{/qword} of youth, the dialectical complement of another misconception the young are noted for—the conviction that they are immortal.

More important than any of this, he offered himself as an incarnation of constitutional propriety so that, temperamentally stubborn, he was careful never to exceed the limits of a {qword}prerogative{/qword} overexploited by the later Stuarts.
The secularization of the Presidency is indispensable for the reassertion of congressional and popular {qword}prerogative{/qword}.

et: Middle English {it}prerogatif, prerogative,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}praerogātīva{/it} "the Roman century on which the lot fell to vote first, the verdict of that century (seen as predicting the outcome of the whole vote), omen, prior choice, prior right or claim," (short for {it}centuria praerogātīva{/it} "century voting first"), from feminine of {it}praerogātīvus{/it} "appointed by lot to vote first," from {it}prae-{/it} {et_link|pre-|pre-} + {it}rogātus,{/it} past participle of {it}rogāre{/it} "to ask, ask (an assembly for a decision)" + {it}-īvus{/it} {et_link|-ive|-ive} {ma}{mat|rogation|}{/ma}

Latin {it}praerogātīvus{/it} was probably formed in the manner indicated, rather than as a derivative of {it}praerogāre{/it} "to ask or propose beforehand, pay in advance," not attested before the 4th century {sc}A.D.{/sc}
shortdef: an exclusive or special right, power, or privilege: such as
one belonging to an office or an official body
one belonging to a person, group, or class of individuals
